questions.text: During an eye examination, a 40-year-old patient presented with complaints of blurred vision and difficulty reading. While performing keratometry, it was observed that the horizontal meridian exhibited a higher degree of curvature compared to the vertical meridian. Based on these findings, the likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Against the Rule Astigmatism

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. With the rule astigmatism - With the rule astigmatism is characterized by a greater curvature of the cornea in the vertical meridian than in the horizontal meridian

 

Option C. Oblique astigmatism - In this type, the steepest curve lies in an oblique axis, neither horizontal nor vertical.

 

Option D. Bioblique astigmatism - This occurs when both principal meridians are oblique and at different angles that are neither vertical nor horizontal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Against the rule astigmatism is when the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. This type of astigmatism is commonly corrected with glasses or contact lenses that have the appropriate cylindrical correction.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 36

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient who previously underwent cataract surgery resulting in aphakia is prescribed spectacles for visual correction. She has been using the spectacles regularly, and now complains of experiencing a specific type of visual impairment or blind spot. What type of scotoma do you think she may have developed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Roving Ring Scotoma

 

Option D:

 

Aphakia means absence of crystalline lens from the eye. It produces high degree of hypermetropia, which it has to be treated with Convex lenses.

 

  • The modalities of correction can be:
    1. Spectacles (like in this case)
    2. Contact lens
    3. Introcular lens
    4. Refractive corneal surgery

 

  • Disadvantages of such high-power spectacles include -
    • Image appears magnified (30%)
    • Spherical aberration
    • Chromatic aberration
    • Limited field of vision
    • Prismatic effect
    • Roving ring scotoma (JACK IN THE BOX PHENOMENON)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Siedel scotoma - This is associated with a glaucomatous defect near the blind spot and is not related to the correction of aphakia with spectacles.

 

Option B. Scintillating scotoma - This is a type of visual aura commonly associated with migraine, which appears as a flickering, jagged arc of light.

 

Option C. Bjerrum scotoma - This is a visual field defect associated with glaucoma, typically a wedge-shaped scotoma extending from the blind spot horizontally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In aphakic patients corrected with spectacles, a roving ring scotoma can develop due to peripheral visual field distortions caused by the prismatic effect of the strong plus lens required to correct the absence of the crystalline lens.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 32

questions.text: What is the total dioptric power in a Donders’ reduced eye model?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) + 60D

 

Option B: The concept of reduced eye: Instead of the eye being a combination of multiple refracting surfaces (cornea, aqueous humor, lens, vitreous humor), it is imagined as a single, ideal spherical refracting surface to understand the focusing mechanism of the eye as an optical device.

 

PARAMETERS IN DONDER’S REDUCED EYE MODEL

 

  • Principal Point – 1.5mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Nodal Point – 7.2mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Anterior Focal Point – 15.7mm in front of anterior surface of cornea
  • Posterior Focal Point – 24.23mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Total Dioptric Power +60D (+43D cornea and +17D lens)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. +58.64D: This value is close to the actual combined dioptric power of the human eye, but it's slightly less than the standard value used for the reduced eye model.

 

Option C. +43D: This value is the power of the cornea in the reduced eye model.

 

Option D. +53D: This is also lower than the typical total dioptric power of the human eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total dioptric power of the reduced eye, a simplified model of the human eye, is conventionally set at +60 diopters, encompassing the combined refractive powers of the cornea and the lens.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 26

choices.text: This procedure uses Excimer Laser
Done in Myopes > 21 years of age
Needs a stable Refractive Error

questions.text: All are true regarding LASIK except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indicated in Keratoconus

 

Option D:

 

  • Laser assisted in situ keratomileusis, or LASIK is done with the excimer laser.
  • Patient selection criteria:
    • Minimum 21 years of age.
    • Stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
    • Have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
    • Corneal thinning disorders (like Keratoconus) that lead to curvatural myopia have been ruled out.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This procedure uses excimer laser: True. LASIK surgery uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea, which corrects refractive errors like myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism.

 

Option B. Done in myopes > 21 years of age: True. LASIK is typically performed on patients over the age of 21 when the refractive error is more likely to have stabilized.

 

Option C. Needs a stable refractive error: True. A stable refractive error for at least a year is one of the prerequisites for LASIK, to ensure the long-term effectiveness of the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LASIK should not be performed on patients with keratoconus.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 74

questions.text: Conductive Keratoplasty is a treatment option for refractive error between:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) +1D to +2.5D

 

Option A:

 

 

  • Concept of Corneal keratoplasty:
    • It is nonablative and nonincisional.
    • Multiple radially distributed spots in the paracentral cornea leads to shrinkage of the collagen in the mid-peripheral stroma and consequent steepening of the central cornea.

 

 

Schematic diagrams of thermokeratoplasty and conductive keratoplasty. Heat shrinks the peripheral cornea, causing central steepening (arrows)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. +2.5D to +4D: This range represents moderate hyperopia. CK can also be effective in this range, though its effectiveness and predictability tend to decrease as the degree of hyperopia increases.

 

Option C. +4D to +10D: This range is more indicative of high hyperopia. CK is generally not recommended for refractive errors in this range due to decreased effectiveness and increased risk of complications.

 

Option D. +10D to +12.5D: This range represents very high hyperopia, where CK is not typically used. Such high levels of hyperopia often require more invasive surgical procedures for correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate range for the use of Conductive Keratoplasty for refractive error correction is +1D to +2.5D, which covers mild hyperopia, where the procedure is most effective and commonly indicated.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 76

2. https://eyewiki.aao.org/Conductive_Keratoplasty

questions.text: LASIK is used to correct myopia upto how many dioptres?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) <8 D

 

Option C. <8 D: While LASIK can correct myopia of less than 8 dioptres, this limit is more conservative than the actual capability of the procedure.

 

LASIK can correct:

 

  • Myopia <8D
  • Hyperopia <4 D
  • Astigmatism < 6D

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. <2 D: This range is too low. LASIK can correct myopia beyond 2 dioptres (D).

 

Option B. <10 D: LASIK is not commonly used to correct myopia in this range. Implantable Contact Lens or Refractive Lens exchange are preferred procedures in this range of myopia.

 

Option D. <20 D: Correcting myopia of less than 20 dioptres with LASIK is generally considered too high and is associated with increased risks and potential complications. Implantable Contact Lens or Refractive Lens exchanges are preferred procedures in this range of myopia

 

Educational Objective:

 

LASIK can effectively and safely correct myopia up to approximately -8 dioptres, which is the standard acceptable range for this procedure.

 

Ref: Pg 377/ theory & practise of optics & refraction/ 4th edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Minimal residual corneal thickness should be 450 microns
The minimum age for LASIK is above 18 years
Contact lens wear should be continued until procedure

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding LASIK procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contact lens wear should be continued until procedure

 

Option C: LASIK criteria:

 

  • Motivated patient.
  • Age > 18 years.
  • Central corneal thickness should be at least 450 microns.
  • Done under topical anesthesia.
  • Contact lens wear should be discontinued. 7 days before surgery for soft contact lenses and 10 days before surgery for rigid contact lenses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Minimal Residual Corneal Thickness Should be 450 Microns: This is true. A minimum residual corneal thickness is required post LASIK to ensure there's enough corneal tissue for reshaping and to maintain the integrity and health of the cornea post-surgery.

 

Option B. The Minimum Age for LASIK is Above 18 Years: This is true. The minimum age for undergoing LASIK is typically 18 years, as it's important for the refractive error to have stabilized, which usually happens around or after this age.

 

Option D. Done under Topical Anesthesia: This is true. LASIK surgery is usually performed under topical anesthesia (eye drops), which numbs the surface of the eye. This allows the procedure to be pain-free for the patient.

 

Therefore, the false statement regarding LASIK procedure is C. Contact Lens Wear Should be Continued until Procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contact lens wear should be discontinued for a period before a LASIK procedure. Contact lenses can alter the shape of the cornea, and discontinuing their use allows the cornea to return to its natural shape, ensuring accurate measurements and a successful surgery.

 

Ref: Pg 366/ theory & practise of optics & refraction/ 4th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which among the following is not a contraindication for LASIK?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age > 18 years

 

Option A: CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR LASIK

 

ABSOLUTE

 

  • Keratoconus
  • Contact lens warpage
  • Glaucoma
  • Herpes simplex keratitis
  • Connective tissue disease

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Keratoconus: This is a contraindication for LASIK. Keratoconus, a condition where the cornea thins and bulges into a cone-like shape, can worsen with LASIK surgery.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Active, uncontrolled glaucoma can be a contraindication for LASIK. The surgery can increase intraocular pressure, which can be detrimental in glaucoma patients.

 

Option D. Blepharitis: This, a chronic inflammatory condition of the eyelids, can be a contraindication for LASIK. It increases the risk of postoperative infection and can affect the healing process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options, an age greater than 18 years is not a contraindication for LASIK surgery. In fact, it is a requirement, as LASIK is generally recommended for adults with a stable refractive error.

 

Ref: Pg 367/ theory & practise of optics & refraction/ 4th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 22-year-old female underwent LASIK procedure for right eye. What does the postoperative management include?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Explanation:

 

POST OPERATIVE MANAGEMENT:

 

  • Patching/ Dark Goggles
  • Systemic Analgesics
  • Antibiotic Drops
  • Topical Steroids
  • Artificial Tears

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-operative medications for LASIK surgery include topical antibiotic eyedrops, topical steroid eyedrops and systemic analgecics.

 

Ref: Pg 383/ theory & practise of optics & refraction/ 4th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What is true for SMILE surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Small Incision Lenticule Extraction

 

Option B: SMILE

 

Small Incision Lenticule Extraction

 

  • Refractive surgery
  • Extraction of refractive lenticule
  • Through a small cut in the corneal flap
  • Can be done manually or with femto laser.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Small incision Lens extraction: It is a method of extracapsular cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Also known as Phacoemulsification: Phacoemulsification is a method of extracapsular cataract surgery.

 

Option D. Partial thickness keratoplasty: Also known as lamellar corneal grafting, this is a type of corneal transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMILE is a type of refractive surgery.

 

Ref: Pg 396/ theory & practise of optics & refraction/ 4th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What is SMILE refractive surgery done on?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cornea

 

Option A:

 

SMILE is a refractive surgery done on cornea.

 

  • Extraction of refractive lenticule
  • Through a small cut in the corneal flap
  • Can be done manually or with femtolaser

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lens: Surgeries performed on lens are cataract surgery and refractive lens exchange.

 

Option C. Retina: Surgical procedures on the retina are typically related to treating retinal diseases, like retinal detachment or macular degeneration.

 

Option D. Vitreous: Vitreous surgeries are generally conducted for conditions like vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMILE refractive surgery is a corneal procedure used to correct myopia and astigmatism by reshaping the cornea through the removal of a small, lens-shaped tissue created using a laser.

 

Ref: Pg 396 / theory & practise of optics & refraction/ 4th edition/ AK KHURANA
